author: Graham Finley
title: Kristen Sieh’s star turn can’t save ludicrous adaptation of Greek tragedy
text:
Considering that “Iphigenia in Aulis” is a classic Greek tragedy — it is about a common who will have to kill his daughter to secure the gods’ blessing — you do not genuinely count on a chorus wearing hippie-hootenanny outfits, or a heroine in a towering macramé hat.
Or possibly you’ll wonder regardless of whether Achilles’ resemblance to Michael Beck in “The Warriors” — 1970s haircut, red hairband, stilted tough-guy acting — is intentional or not, and why the cast is forced to climb on and off an elevated platform.
But the largest puzzlement behind this production’s disjointed, incoherent tone — as when the cartoonish Achilles (Rob Campbell) faces a tragic Clytemnestra (Amber Gray) — is that it was place together by two clever cookies. Adapter Anne Washburn gave us the sharp, offbeat “Mr. Burns” and “10 Out of 12,” though director Rachel Chavkin was behind the inventively staged “Natasha, Pierre and the Fantastic Comet of 1812” and “Small Mouth Sounds.”
Excellent accomplishments, all. But in “Iphigenia,” the audience is caught in a frantic whirlwind — have I described the live folk-rock music? — that fails to create emotional traction.
Except, that is, when Kristen Sieh takes center stage as Iphigenia. It is a commanding performance despite its intimate scale, in particular when Iphigenia delivers an impassioned monologue to plead for her life. It fails to convince her dad (Campbell once again), so Iphigenia rationalizes her impending death by morphing from sacrificial lamb to willing heroine — and Sieh, standing practically still, brilliantly captures both modes. She makes the busyness that surrounds these scenes seem yet much more ludicrous.
